title: 10 Effective Ways to Deodorize Clothes Without Washing Them

steps.title: Turn sweaty clothes inside out and make a diluted vinegar spray.
steps.content: Turn sweaty clothes inside out and make a diluted vinegar spray. Just fill a clean bottle with equal parts white vinegar and water. Then, spritz it over the smelly fabric. [1] X Expert Source Susan Stocker House Cleaning Professional Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. Let the fabric dry completely—the vinegar smell and the odor should disappear! [2] X Research source Don't use apple cider vinegar since the distinctive smell might not fade completely.

steps.title: Fill a spray bottle with straight vodka and spritz it onto the stinky spots.
steps.content: Fill a spray bottle with straight vodka and spritz it onto the stinky spots. This also works with vintage clothes that have a musty smell. The alcohol in the vodka clings to the smell so it disappears as the vodka evaporates! Just make sure you don't use fruity or flavored vodka. [3] X Research source It's totally fine to use cheap vodka for this. It's just as effective as a top-shelf bottle. Alcohol could discolor dark fabrics so don't use this spray on dark jeans or clothes.

steps.title: Mix 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of lemon juice with 3⁄4 c (180 ml) of water.
steps.content: Mix 1 US tbsp (15 ml) of lemon juice with 3 ⁄ 4 c (180 ml) of water. Pour your homemade deodorizer into a clean spray bottle and spritz it all over your smelly clothes. Then, hang them up to dry. [4] X Research source This spray works best for white clothes since the lemon juice could bleach your colorful clothes.

steps.title: Seal the bag and shake it so the fabric's coated with the scent.
steps.content: Seal the bag and shake it so the fabric's coated with the scent. Then, leave the clothes in the sealed bag for about 10 minutes so the fresh smell is strong. When you take them out, you'll have clothes that smell brand new! [5] X Research source If you're deodorizing black clothing, check it when you take it out of the bag. If you see white residue from the dryer sheet, just brush it off.

steps.title: Fold your items and put them in a sealable bag.
steps.content: Fold your items and put them in a sealable bag. Then, pop it in the freezer overnight. When you check on your clothes in the morning, the stinky smell should be gone! [6] X Research source It's thought that cold temperatures can kill odor-causing bacteria.

steps.title: Shake out stinky clothes and hang them out in the sunshine.
steps.content: Shake out stinky clothes and hang them out in the sunshine. If you've got sweaty workout clothes and no time to wash them, don't leave them wadded up in your gym bag! Sometimes, just taking them out and hanging them on a drying rack on a clothesline in the sunshine can work wonders. [7] X Research source Give the clothes a few hours to air out before you check to see if they're still smelly. Sunlight can kill bacteria on clothes, but it can also fade fabrics so you may want to put vibrant-colored clothes in the shade or on a drying rack in your home.

steps.title: Buy antibacterial spray designed for laundry if you need a quick fix.
steps.content: Buy antibacterial spray designed for laundry if you need a quick fix. Take your smelly clothes and hang them up. Then, spray the clothes all over with the deodorizing spray. It should instantly freshen up your musty or stinky clothes. [8] X Research source Toss one of these sprays in your bag if you're traveling or you hit the gym.

steps.title: Stir a few spoonfuls of water into baking soda to make a thick paste.
steps.content: Stir a few spoonfuls of water into baking soda to make a thick paste. Turn your clothes inside out and rub the paste onto the stinky areas. This works really well for armpit odors, for instance. Once the paste dries, brush it off and turn your clothes right side out. [9] X Research source You can probably brush off the dried paste by hand, but if it's not coming off easily wipe it with a dry brush.

steps.title: Take a cloth bag and fill it with charcoal to absorb musty odors.
steps.content: Take a cloth bag and fill it with charcoal to absorb musty odors. This is super helpful if you're storing clothes for a while in a musty closet where not a lot of air circulates. If you don't have vegetable charcoal, fill the bag with uncooked rice and a few sprigs of herbs like rosemary or lavender. [10] X Research source The uncooked rice can absorb moisture from the closet that makes your clothes smell in the first place. Although this isn't a quick deodorizing trick, it can really keep your clothes smelling fresh in between uses.

steps.title: Pop a scented sachet into your drawers to keep your clothes fresh.
steps.content: Pop a scented sachet into your drawers to keep your clothes fresh. This is also a great trick if you'll be traveling—just tuck a pouch into your suitcase. To make a scented sachet, pour all these ingredients into a cloth bag and seal it closed: [11] X Research source 2 cups (420 g) of uncooked rice 40 drops of essential oils like lavender 1 cup (53 g) of dried rosemary
